G. 1.2 × 10^-5

H. 2.0 × 10^-5

I. 6.0 × 10^-5

J. 3.5 × 10^-5

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Oh! Wait a minute, the question says "the mutation rate," which typically refers to the rate per locus, meaning that each mutation introduces one copy of the beneficial allele. So, if the mutation rate is μ, the frequency of the beneficial allele after mutation would be p + μ (since each mutation introduces one copy). But considering selection, the actual frequency would be p' = [p + μ] / [1 + (1 - p)(1 - μ)]. For small μ and p, this approximates to p' ≈ p + μ - p(1 - μ) ≈ p + μ - p + pμ ≈ μ. So, setting p' = p, we get μ ≈ s * p. Which brings us back to μ = 0.6 * (1/8000) = 7.5e-5. Since this isn't an option, perhaps the intended answer is C (3e-5), assuming they rounded down. Alternatively, maybe the formula is μ = (s * N) / (1 + s*N), which would be (0.6*8000)/(1+4800)=4800/4801≈0.99975e-3, which is ~1e-3, still not matching. I'm really stuck here. Given the available options, I think the closest is C (3e-5), but I'm not fully confident.
</think>
The correct answer is C
